field_edited_text.value:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways





been constructed and this type is relatively common.

A few early examples of urban expressways also exist. The Pulaski
Skyway from the Newark Airport to the Holland Tunnel is one such.
No motorist who endeavored to negotiate the northern New Jersey indus-
trial flats prior to its construction will forget the fantastic congestion
which then existed on the surface streets. Hours were required to cover a
few miles. The West Side Highway in New York City running south
from 72nd Street is another early example. We don’t often think of the
Orleans Street Viaduct here in Baltimore as an expressway, but this is
essentially what it is. It has performed satisfactorily for some twenty-
five years.

Despite these early examples it is only within the last few years that
a large-scale program of urban expressways has gotten under way in cities
all over the country. Even now only a few hundred miles of urban ex-
pressways have been completed and are in use.

Expressways Are Safer

There appears to be no doubt whatsoever that expressways are much
safer than normal city streets. Statistics assembled on this subject over
a number of years by the U. S. Bureau of Public Roads show that urban
expressways are approximately twice as safe as city streets in terms of
fatal accidents and approximately five times as safe in terms of total
accidents. The record to date shows a cumulative fatality rate of 2.3 per
hundred million vehicle miles on urban expressways compared to 4.2 for
other city streets. The corresponding figures for all accidents are 154
and 751.

The Morning Sun for August 4, 1959, commented editorially on this
subject as follows:

“The statistics building up both in Maryland and elsewhere

22

show how much safer controlled access highways are. Nationwide,
the turnpikes like the New Jersey and Pennsylvania turnpikes and
the New York Thruway are the most striking examples of roadside
control. And despite the higher speeds allowed, they are definitely
safer. It was recently announced that the death rate for turnpikes
in 1958 was only 1.3 for every 100,000,000 vehicle miles. It was 2.3—
almost double—for other highways and roads.

“Right here in Maryland a small but significant sample tells a
similar story. Both US Route 13 from Salisbury to the Virginia
line and US Route 40 from Baltimore to Frederick have portions of
highway with controlled access and portions with unlimited access.
The controlled portions were markedly safer. The State Roads
Commission reports that on Route 13 there were no fatal accidents
at all last year on the controlled stretch compared to a rate of 12.4
deaths per 100,000,000 vehicle miles on the unlimited portion of the
dual highway. On Route 40, the rate was 3.4 on the controlled
stretch against a 9.8 figure for the unlimited access part of it just
outside Baltimore City.

“True, these figures are based on happily few deaths in each
case. One bad two-car accident anywhere could wrench the statistics
into a quite different relationship. But the experience on other high-
ways with tight roadside control suggests rather that the first com-
parable figures here in Maryland are following the normal pattern.
If the argument for beauty alone has failed to move Maryland’s
legislators as much as it should, perhaps the growing argument for
safety will help turn them into proponents of truly tight roadside
control of new super-highways.”

While the examples and statistics cited in this editorial refer to rural
rather than urban expressways, the Sun correctly points to control of
